body:
Hi,

I'm on Windows 10, Python 3.7.1, Cython 0.29.7.

I have some pure python code that I wanted to compile that uses
`from __future__ import annotations`, but compiling it throws:
```
Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-

from __future__ import annotations
                      ^
------------------------------------------------------------

app.py:6:23: future feature annotations is not defined
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "D:\app\compile_with_cython.py", line 59, in <module>
    main()
  File "D:\app\compile_with_cython.py", line 54, in main
    language_level=3,
  File "C:\Python37\lib\site-packages\Cython\Build\Dependencies.py", line 1097, in cythonize
    cythonize_one(*args)
  File "C:\Python37\lib\site-packages\Cython\Build\Dependencies.py", line 1220, in cythonize_one
    raise CompileError(None, pyx_file)
Cython.Compiler.Errors.CompileError: app/app.py
```
It is used to type annotate some `self` method parameters that need to reference itself.
I'm guessing that this is a not yet supported feature of CPython 3.7? Is there a way to bypass this without removing the `from __future__ import annotations` code?

Matic

comment_data.body:
#2863 was closed as done by #3285 (which made it into Cython version 0.29.15), but the reported issue is still a problem (ie, was not a duplicate).

Still generates future feature annotations is not defined error.

I'm not sure if I get the problem correctly, but `from __future__ import annotations` is basically a CPython hack to get a Python 4 behavior.  With GH-3285 merged, this can be achieved by setting `binding=True`.

@McSinyx The problem is that `from __future__ import annotations` should still be valid code. Although the feature is always enabled in Cython (post https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3285)  the `__future__` statement shouldn't break anything.

However @shaolo1 as far as I can tell it didn't make it in to 0.29.15. It's in the changelog for Cython 3.0. Given that 0.29.x doesn't support to, generating an error message is the correct behaviour. If you download the "master" branch it'll work.

> should still be valid code

Yes. It should just be ignored, as with all outdated "future" imports.

> > should still be valid code
> 
> Yes. It should just be ignored, as with all outdated "future" imports.

Yes - that is what happens (in the master branch).

@McSinyx enabling binding did not fix the problem.  (also tried setting on command line with cython -X binding=True foo.py)

```
# cython: language_level=3, binding=True

from __future__ import annotations
                      ^
------------------------------------------------------------

foo.py:3:23: future feature annotations is not defined

```
@shalolo1, I think as mentioned above, it is fixed in `master`.  What I say was that enabling `binding` gives you the same effect.
@McSinyx I tried enabling binding as you suggested.  It did not help.  So, I guess I'm confused as to what binding has to do with it.
@da-woods, @McSinyx  Yes, using master does indeed ignore the import (and setting binding was not required).  Thanks!

title: Python 3.7: from __future__ import annotations
